title: Hands-on project and data analysis
text: The students will be randomly divided into groups of approximately 4 people. For this project, the students will be given a synthetic multi-omics dataset; the objective is to perform data integration analyses and to present the results during an oral presentation (tentative date: 30rd October 2025).

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course description
“Omics and Data-Driven Precision Health” is an interdisciplinary course that bridges the gap between artificial intelligence (AI) and precision health, focusing on the application of AI and machine learning technologies that are transforming personalized healthcare.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Course content
The course content includes introductions to omics technologies and an overview of core AI and ML principles, such as supervised and unsupervised learning, neural networks, and deep learning. Additionally, the applications of AI and ML in multi-omics analysis for disease diagnostics and treatment optimization will be discussed.

Topics covered:

Introduction to Omics Technologies: Overview of the omics field and the development of omics technologies.
Principles of AI, ML, and Network Analysis: Fundamental techniques and applications in AI and ML.
Translational Omics and Precision Health: Focus on biomarkers and their role in precision health.
Applications of AI in Healthcare: Examples of how AI can support diagnosis and treatment.
Ethical, Legal, and Social Aspects: Discussion on ethical issues related to AI use in healthcare, including privacy and equality.
Practical Project and Data Analysis: Hands-on experience through a group-based project involving omics data analysis.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Learning Objectives and Learning Outcomes
Upon completing the course, students are expected to achieve the following:

Knowledge and understanding

Describe the principles of AI applied to precision health and identify the challenges in healthcare that these technologies aim to address.
Explain the roles of AI technologies in analyzing biomedical data for disease diagnostics, treatment optimization, and the development of personalized healthcare solutions.
Understand and distinguish the capabilities and limitations of various AI and machine learning (ML) methods in the context of precision health, including supervised and unsupervised learning, neural networks, and deep learning.
Explain the significance of multi-omics analysis in precision health and how AI technologies facilitate the interpretation of complex biological information.



Skills and Abilities

Utilize advanced methods for integrating multi-omics data.
Apply AI and ML methods to solve problems in precision medicine.
Analyze and interpret biomedical data using AI-driven methods.



Critical Thinking and Approach

Demonstrate a critical approach when selecting and applying AI and ML methods in biomedical research to ensure the reliability and validity of results.
Discuss the ethical, legal, and social implications of using AI in healthcare, with a focus on privacy, data security, and equitable access to medical innovations.

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Target audience and course prerequisites
Target audience: This course is designed for PhD students, postdocs, and researchers with an interest in omics technologies and explores how different omics fields contribute to strategies for personalized healthcare. Course prerequisites: none Level: beginner/intermediate

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Forms of instruction and examination
Forms of instruction: In-person (week 41), Online (week 44) Forms of study: Lectures, workshops, seminars, data project Language: English
Examination: The course assessment consists of individual written assignments, a mandatory group project with an oral presentation, and active participation in seminars. Attendance at the presentation session is required for a passing grade. Students who do not achieve a passing grade will be given one opportunity for re-examination shortly after the course ends. Additional examination opportunities will be available during future course offerings. The scope of the re-examination will be the same as that of the original examination. Grading Scale: Pass or Fail

title: Course Syllabus
text:
Additional notes

This course is highly interactive and hence it is important that you, as a participant, actively contribute to all sessions and elements of the course.
Basic knowledge of R or Python
Participants need to bring a laptop

title: Module 4: Translational omics and precision health
text:
Summary



In this module we will present some of the applications of translational omics research, with particular focus on precision health.

title: Module 4: Translational omics and precision health
text:
Morning lecture
The lecture will cover some of the applications of multi-omics analysis, drawing examples from the literature, such as:

Biomarker discovery.
Population health and precision health.
Drug discovery and development.

title: Module 4: Translational omics and precision health
text:
Seminar
The students will be given a paper on the topic of the module to read, that will be discussed during the seminar.

title: Module 3: Principles of artificial intelligence, machine learning and network analysis
text:
Summary



A massive number of tools are available for bioinformatic analyses. In this module we will guide the students across the most important categories of analyses that can be performed. We will look at classical tools, e.g. linear regression, as well as more recent approaches, e.g. neural networks. After this module, the students will:

Have an overview of the different types of analyses that concern omic data.
Be able to perform these analyses on their data.

title: Module 3: Principles of artificial intelligence, machine learning and network analysis
text:
Morning lecture
The lecture will cover a broad spectrum of analyses that can be performed, such as:

High-dimensionality reduction techniques.
Clustering: supervised and unsupervised.
Regression
Reinforcement machine learning
Network analysis
Generative AI, transfer learning and explainable AI During this lecture, we will present what goals we can achieve with these tools, together with their limitations.

title: Module 3: Principles of artificial intelligence, machine learning and network analysis
text:
Afternoon workshop
During the workshop, we will present the main R/Python packages that can be used to perform the analyses discussed during the lectures. Examples with code will be provided.

title: Module 3: Principles of artificial intelligence, machine learning and network analysis
text:
Seminar
The students will be given a paper on the topic of the module to read, that will be discussed during the seminar. Active partcipation during the seminar is a requirement to pass.

title: Module 1: Introduction to omics technologies
text:
Summary



The field of omic data analysis has been rapidly evolving during the last two decades. Moreover, the importance of bioinformatics in biomedical research has steadily continued to increase, becoming an almost a required skill for any researcher in the field. Throughout this module, the students will:

Obtain a comprehensive overview of the available omics.
Learn which omic may be more suitable for a given research question.
Learn how to analyze several types of omics.

title: Module 1: Introduction to omics technologies
text:
Morning lecture
We will start the lecture with a brief historical review of the omics field. Commonly used omic technologies, such as genomics, epigenetics, transcriptomics, proteomics and metabolomics, will be presented throughtout the lecture. We will also talk about the present trends of omics technologies and possible future developments. In particular, we will mention recent advances such as single-cell (2012) and spatial omics (2022) data.

title: Module 1: Introduction to omics technologies
text:
Afternoon workshop
In this first workshop we will present bioinformatic pipelines for the analysis of some common omics. We will mainly focus on the initial processing and quality control (downstream analysis will be covered in the following modules). While some of same principles can found in the analysis of multiple omics, some omics require special software/packages; our aim with this workshop is to teach which tools should be used depending on the omic. We will provide basic pipelines for the analysis of different omic data, such as whole-genome sequencing, single-cell RNA-seq and Olink proteomics.

title: Module 1: Introduction to omics technologies
text:
Lectures and Materials
A markdown tutorial will be uploaded before the workshop.

title: Teachers
text:
Wen Zhong []https://orcid.org/0000-0002-7422-6104)  

Assistant Professor, Linköping, Department of Biomedical and Clinical Sciences (BKV)





Wen Zhong mainly focuses on the integration of multi-omics, the interplay between genetics and phenotypes, and the development of data-driven strategies/tools for precision medicine. The aim is to investigate the molecular biomarkers for the estimation of disease risks, early diagnosis of disease, stratification of drug treatment response, disease progression monitoring and the stratification of patients.

title: Module 2: Omics integration
text:
Summary



Analyzing paired omics generated from the same biological samples promises to give a more holistic view of the biological processes. However, there remain several practical questions on how to integrate multi-omics effectively. In this module we will present what strategies are currently used by researchers for this purpose. After this module, the students will:

Know what are the advantages of multi-omics approaches.
Be able to implement state-of-the-art analyses for multi-omics integration.

title: Module 2: Omics integration
text:
Morning lecture
In the lecture we will discuss the advantages of multi-omics data; positive examples from the literature will be shown to highlight the potential benefits. We will present multiple strategies that have been successfully adopted by researchers to integrate multi-omics data. Pitfalls and open questions regarding multi-omics integration will also be discussed.

title: Module 2: Omics integration
text:
Afternoon workshop
In this workshop we will take a look at available tools for multi-omics integration as well as versatile analysis strategies that can be used for multiple multi-omics.
